projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

div.p: PROGNOSTICON Posthumum. 1643/4.
Exactly calculated to the Meridion of London, and may indifferently serue for all England.
By way of Caution, to the people of England, Scotland, and Ireland, that shall happen to reade NA-VVORTH.
As an Appendix to Maister Iohn Bookers Mercurius Coelicus.
Written by S. M.
LONDON, Printed by a more warrantable Licence then Domino D. Arch. Cant. Secellanus Domesticus. 1643.

div.head: His name is Nabal, and folly is with him. No-worth, 1644. A new ALMINACK and Prognostication for the yeare of our Saviour, 1644.
div.p: HAD I met his name in the third collumn of his Alminack, under the title of Saints: I should have thought the Divell, hath transformed himselfe into an Angell of Light, a Prognostication; and yet hee saith himselfe in the page of December, in his new Rubrick that for the yeare yet to come, hee can give you no account as yet, no nor I beleeve, for that that's past, you see what to trust too, a Prognostication worth nothing: neverthelesse, as Britannicus observed concerning Aulicus, he hath the faculty of ralying a routed Regiment into a story, and claimes Christ as a Saviour, when he is unwilling to call this, the yeare of our Redemption, being the bissextile or leap yeare.

What this bissextile yeare is, he tells you, Subtitulo, leap yeare, and that it is nothing but a day gotten by the surplus of 6 howers every year, and this is one Doctors opinion, then I may adde mine too.

It is leap yeare where the Surplis has got by Spirituall fornication, a child of Idolatry, when the Surplis has got a rent, and may be added among his Cronologicall Occurrences, Ian. 18. 1643. Such a leap year, where he like Aulicus, hath leapt over Gods providence, turning the truth of God into a lye, under the title of—
With a cronologie of the most remarkeable Occurrences since the beginning of this Rebellion, calculated exactly for the latitude and meridian of the famouus Vniversity of Oxford, by GEORGE NAVVORTH.

IT should seem by his own Oxford Calculation, that this Rebellion was calculated at Oxford, and Mercurius Aulicus was his pole-stare, since the whole Court moves upon that beares taile, had Naworth set his instrument Meridionall, hee might have found Berkenhead, alias Bufflehead, 53. degrees high in impieties Sunday, the 28. of Ianuary, 1643. Printed at Oxford by his Majesties speciall command.

We have good thoughts and loyall hearts to his Majesty, but we will conclude that his Majesty rules not there, because Plato saith, nature may sooner erre, then a Prince frame a Common Wealth unlike himselfe.
But I come to his Alminack it selfe, and we begin with his perfect table of the foure Tearmes, &c.

I can but wonder why he takes the paines to tell the foure tearms of the yeare, since they are lawlesse where he lives, and cannot adjourn the tearme to Oxford, or that hee takes notice of dayes of exception, and never remember, why Cottington, Byron, &c. were accepted against, or dayes of appearance, Ian. 22. 1643, where one acts in a Spanish cloak, and another like the Prelate of the garter or Palatine Bishop, reads service in a head-peece, and all to make up Englands tragidy compleat.

And why should we note that the Exchequer opens, except he lookes for the golden
number, there, he saith it is 11. but in that contradicts the Lord Goring's letter, who saith, all was pawnd but the great coller of SS. which has made the circle of the Sunns but 1, who is heire to three Kindomes, he taxes our thoughts, we know not yours, when you mention his Majesty to be affraid to adde, whom God grant long to raigne, and now since you have led me to the Dominion of the Moone in mans body.

Me thinks I see a gracious King sitting, I feare setting in your Horizon li • e the Anot • my, naked, open to a feminine planet; Digbies Bull, holding him by the shoulders, threatning excommunication. Gemine, Rupert and Maurice claming his ar •• es. Libra ♎ in his loynes, Justice and equity: manhood in his heart. Leo ♌ the ancient badg of his Royal Predecessors, but on a slippery foundation, a feminine signe. Giue the King thy judgment ô God, and keep his feet from sliding.

q.l: When as the Major did rule the Towne,
But when the boy his Mother rul'd,
The Towne was rul'd by Iohn.

div.head: IANVARY hath XXXI dayes.
div.p: THis month it seems hath nothing so remarkable as the 10th day, when his Majesty left his faithfull Councell by White-hall, going from a Court of Justice to a seminary of—I know you will confesse a Tub is no fit residence for Alexander, but Diogenes, Philosophers best sort with their Accademies. Precipibus Metropolis, 'tis a University phrase: pray pardon the expression; where is the Metropolis, is it not London? where is the chiefe Court, but Parliament, not where tumults molested him, but where the vote of a Kingdome would make him the happiest Prince alive: hee takes notice of the 19. 22. and 27. of Ianuary, and yet remembers not Gods mercies renewed every day: me thinks I look upon his phrase of Rebels, as on the bastard that threw stones among a tumult as hee calls it, and am willing to give him that admonition to take heed he do not hit his father Pater Errorum, as Mr. Iohn Booker stiles him.

div.head: FEBRVARY hath XXIX dayes.
div.p: ANd here you had need of just action, that you may understand his lying kallender, it hath 6. collumns: the first is titled dayes of the month, the second is dayes of the weeke, the third is Holidayes with Saints names. And I question whether the Cannon of &c. be not set downe there as a Canonnicall day? why not Thomas a Becket, and St. William of Canterbury's name, as well as their images at the West end of Pauls.

The next collumn is titled places of the moone at noone, and then the sun rising at Oxford; It seems the greater planet never rises till the moone is up, and so you reckon from he meridian of midnight, and that makes the difference between you at Oxford, and we at London, it seems you do not rise while noon, this was the Marquesse of Newcastles fault, and in this month he hath made two purifications; the one on the second day when they were at their beads, and the other on the 13. day set in great letters, yet I wonder Naworth did not tremble, when such as her Majesty cryed to the hils to cover her, did not thou Naworth fear to give an account of these notorious untruths.

div.head: MARCH hath XXXI dayes.
div.p:
HEre he speaks of the great victory on Hopton heath, & you may see his affection to the Crown of King Charles, for he writes in breviats the dialect of Oxford, as
your Oxford plots are usually written, for next to the day titled in it Reg. Car. he sets Rupert in the collumn of the Saints, and then another breviat Epis, which stands for Bishops, and least Maurice should stand in competition to the Crowne also, he allowes him his succession also under the title of Victor. Mar. victorious Maurice, or in his own language, cowardly Rebell.

div.head: APRIL hath XXX dayes.
div.p:
ANd here he saith, Prince Rupert entred the seditious town of Brumidgham, and it maketh me admire that the young man was not misled seeing — April —you may lead a foole whether yo • wil, but this was not the first day, but Monday, the 3. day, and in this month is his rabical observation of St. Chad, the very same that a Roman Catholike made long since concerning the L. Brook, but I suppose you remember who told you, that is rather an argument against
• athedrals, if not, see what M. Booker saith concerning the day of inventio crucis, me thinks you •• ould put the dates of your new Nobilities patents too in your Chronologie, but that were an argument against your truly noble Lords.

div.head: MAY hath XXXI daies.
div.p:
MAY may produce something more remakeable occurrences to them, therfore hee consecrates a day to Petronel; you see this Alminack speaks in carabine language, and it may be the same day when Col Goodwin surprized t • em by Bril, & took a Cornet, on which was this device, a swor •
& Carbine with this inscription; Ratio ultima raegum, which it may bee, was a concecrated banner to the memory of the great victory he cals it, that the L. Hopton had over the rebels, as his phrase is, when he had spent his powder, and fel to it with swords, pikes, and musket stocks: I beleeve it to be concecrated rather, because I conceave 'twas of her Majesties own regiment, for 'twas on black damask.

div.head: IVNE hath XXX dayes.
div.p:
IVne the 18. his highnes Prince Rupert beat up the quarters at Chinner, & there was slain Mr.
• ohn Hampden accused of high treason, but it was by St. Petronel, as you spoke of, that came into the house armed, and would have acted violence on the person of others, had not God prevented it. Hampdens name is honourable; Decorem e • t pro patria mori, and his bloud is able to beat up your quarters as wel as the blood of Abel cryed for vengeance.

div.head: IVLY hath XXXI dayes
div.p: YOu lye, it hath but 6 in your own account, for Nulla dies sine linea; you have never a day without a great victory, & you had but 5 this month, and a providence, now I see some da • s may passe without a lye, but there are lyes enough in this 6 dayes to victuall the University for 6 months, and allow a lye a day enough to furnish the 3 • dayes withall, and as Mr. Booker well observe • , never was so many lyes under the title of an Alminack, and which is observeable in this month, they left not one rebell on the 13 day, and yet on the 14 day of this month, he saith Pr. Rupert had • oyned his forces to his brothers, and judg then when the whole body of their strength was together, whether that were not a rebellion of the blood royall to deprive his Majesty and his hopefull posterity.

div.head: AVGVST hath XXXI dayes.
div.p:
NAworth is always on the winning side, and though he say much this month he promi • es amendment, for he saith that the 27 day of this month Dog-d • yes end, and then we hope we shall have no more of thi •
Mali-l • gni, such Malignants as himselfe, or such Evil-wood-heads, & we hop further, that Pr. Ru ert who hath yet no more religion then Cor • elius Agrippa that at last left his dog with this Irony. Abi a me, &c. goe from me thou wic • ed beast, that hast undone me, and no doubt but if the devil • , as many think it is in the shape of a dogge, when he perc • ives his Mr. Rupert intends to turn him out of service, h • e'l drown hims • lf as the said Cornelius his dog did at the harsh sentence of his M • ster.

div.head: SEPTEMBER hath XXX dayes,
div.p:
IT should seem they sung Masse at Oxford the 14 day of this month, or else carried the horse from door to door, hence it is termed Exdiatio Crucis. In this month it was where the rebellion of Ireland increased more and more, in England, and his highnesse Prince Maurice made
such a hot assault on Exeter, that he fired the suburbs, in hoc signo vinces, it should seeme great is Dianah. Naworth is not so ingenious in this month as Aulicus (in the report of the victory neare Auburn in Wiltshire, where he saith there was none of No-worth k lled) onely in this, he saies the Queens regiment was commanded by Jermin, but when he tells how the London forces stole toward London, that Rup • rt overtook them with his Majesties horse, and here he speaks like the lying Oracle doubtfull. Caesar passing over the stood Halim, shall overthrew a great army, and so he sait • , the L. Jermin performed so wel on the rebels part, that many great bodyes of foot were routed: alas gracious Ki • g, that suffers himselfe to be misled by the salutat • on of Charles the great, with which Naworth ends his Almanack, & considers not his doubtful meaning in those words, Hierarchiae dignitatis as • rto & •• ndex. Since there is a m • stery of iniquity in Hierarchy.

div.head: OCTOBER hath XXXI dayes.
div.p:
ANd on the first day was his Majesties Commission granted to the Irish to seize to his use all the lands and estates of the English Protestants there, who list to see the Copy of the Comm ssion, may read in the miste • y of iniquity working in the Kingdomes of England, Scotlan • , and I •• land, dated a little before the grand rebellion brake forth there, Octob. 23. On which day he saith, was a convention of all orders, for there was Franciscans, Dominicans, Lins • y & Wool •• y, impure N •
ro • s, fals Sinons, seditious Catalines, and apostate Julians ingaged the K. himself into their grand mischiefe, and emminent dangers, there you might have seen the effect of bad counsel, there was sculking into holes, when the L. Taffe was shot in the mouth, but I wonder why he did not put ln so many Kings too, as well as in the Declaration concerning Brainfor • , where his Ma • esty Clareceux is mentioned, but whether he faught on one side or other, the boy at Kenton can tel.

div.head: NOVEMBER hath XXX dayes.
div.p: ON the first of this month was a convention of saints slain at Edghil, and the day is celebrated in their memory, All Saints, on the 5 day was a seed plot of this grand rebellion, to de •• roy as now the K and Parliament. Powder-treason, and Naworth himself in the plot, and here indeed, he saith the rebels shot against Sion, for the Church was set as a mark, and the Thames wept blood, as sensible of the blood of the guiltlesse, murdered by a Commission of Array, whose blood cryes out, see O Lord the enemies blaspheme thy na • e, and there was their blasphemies against God, their Cannons and Demi cannons. Brainford can witnesse it, and then the Rebels after all this murder stole away to Oxford by an honourable retreate as the forger of these fictonsi calls it.

div.head: DECEMBER hath XXXI dayes.
div.p: I Am so weary in reading this years lyes, being the Court New-years gift, that I do but wonder what he has to answer for all his lying life, and what a New-years-gift, the forger of this Alminack would be to the devil. • f you aske what makes the Astronomer there, where there is neither star nor s • y, I tell you he is there for making many a lye. And in this month he is troubled at a new great seal, and questions whose image and superscription it is, I say unto thee, it is Caesars, but which is greater thou Hypocrite, the gold of the Temple, or the Temple that sanctifies the gold, wee can know your Keeper too, by the Title of 1643, and we • an know Nawo • th by 1641. for yee are of your Father the Devill, his workes yee doe, Redite, and give the Devill his due.

div.head: Observations on his common Notes.
div.p: How much it was, he told you before, what it is, he tells you now, and he dreams of Magnum Annum Platonis, the great yeare of Plato, for this time 19 yeares he saith things will be as they are, and desires the Scots would let him alone till then, and then hee'll write a Recantation: I should rather believe him if he had said, though this Parliament should be dissolved, yet we should have another that time 3 yeare.
In the Circle of the Sun he Calculates, how far he is from Christ, and by his owne Computation he is 59. Revolutions.
By the Dominicall Letter he knowes when tis a Fast at Oxford, it being the Eve before any unmoveable Feast.

You must note that the Epact in nothing else but a number of daies which the common Solar yeare doth exceed the common Lunar yeare, and with them the Compact is
the number that exceed the Major part of the Houses of Parliament, which I feare is not 11. but as he saith, he addes them to Coequate the Parliament at Westminster.

In the Roman Indiction he hath no use of it in England, but onely the Bishops of Rome being a number of 15 yeares, where at every 5th yeares end they received Tribute, the first in Gold, the second in Silver, the third in Brasse. But it should seeme the Bishops of England were Bishops of Rome, witnesse the first 15 years of King Charles, for the first 5 years were golden dais, when they were heads of the Church: The next 5 years he saith, was silver, for Souldiers pay wch made them send Agents to Rome to contribute to the Episcopall wars: And the last 5 yeares, he saith, were paid in brasse and iron for Armour. Now judge who raised this war, who exercised Roman Jndiction? who received Souldiers pay beforeha • d? who provided Armour for Souldiers pay? The Bishops of Rome. And now we hope since, the Colledge Plate is pawned to buy Iron, that this Nebuchadnezzar's Image is falling, his Head Gold, his Breast Silver, his Thighes Brasse, his Leggs Iron, which we hope are his last legs, and stands on clay, since both Nations have protested against Prelacy.

The Winter Quarter is his first quarter Astronomicall, but the last according to our English account (according to our London accompt to, for we hope it shall be your last quarter, therefore seeke out for fresh, I scarce believe the Spring will be welcome to you) and it begins the 11th day of December the last yeare he saith, and his time is so neere that he compts but till the 9 h of March, and then for the Robberies committed this quarter, he shall give an account, and in the meane time he saith the Gallowes groanes for them. I before doubted whether he spake like a Lawyer or an Astronomer in his Computation, but I am now resolved by his words, Winter began the last yeare 1643. which shewes who began this war first, the King, or the Parliament. And he counts the first of August that his Excellency the Earle of Essex disposed of his Souldiers in a Regimentall way, and tells us of many of their owne outrages done 6 monthes before, as in Ianuary 1642. by the L. Hopton neere Bodmin, and at Saltash, and at Brill. In February 1642. Cyrenci • er: In March 1642. at Hopton Heath, when as he saith that the Houses voted not till May, after 1642. that the King intended to make war against his Parliament, I perceive it is as hard to tell what he meanes by 1642. as to know his right hand from his left, except we know whether he looked East, West, North, or South, for if he had looked Easterly, then Durham had beene his right hand, and his safest way, as Mr. Booker saith, I suppose he durst not looke towards the Pole, lest he should have discovered the Scots advance.

In the Spring quarter he casts a Figure, and there is Libra in the Horiscope of Oxford, which signifies an ill life, an ill beginning, and an ill ending, and since I find Fortuna minor in the Angle of the Earth: I conclude that your men of war be furious, and your children is not legitimate, but I conceive because I find ♈ in the 7th House, that there be not many theeves amongst you, all are not lyars at Oxford, though Naworth and Aulicus be two. But forasmuch as I find Leo, which is attributed to Via, in the Angle meridionall, I conceive if Naw • rth goes to the King hee'l Knight him, but withall the F gure tells me he shall neither be King, Emperour, nor Pope, and the same figure saith, it is not good for the King to goe to the war, for he shall be in danger to be taken or lose the Victory. Thus we see we have a hopefull Figure cast by Naworth, which makes us think Naworth will come to no good, nor our King to no harme, onely h • saith • reate disc • ntent a • e likely to arise among their new Nobility, by reason of the
accidentall sight of those that continue yet at Westminster in spight of the opposition of Mars.

And now gentle Reader, it will not doe amisse to trace this Cassandra, and give him this faculty, that though he should speake true, yet that none may believe him, for it should seem he calculates according to the Hipothesis of Copernicus, and places the Earth in Libra, and has read Blau de Globis, and will perswade you that the Earth runs round, and the Sun stands still, and that's the very reason that he calls Routings, Victories all along his Almanack: And so he saith the Summer quarter shall begin when the Earth hath volved her selfe to the farthest limit of the South, or the Sun after an old (Fantasie) hath made his preambulation Northward, and in Autumne, the Earth's Axis paraleld to the Sun's, shall move in its diurnall revolution directly to the Suns Superficies, or the Sun (after common conceit) crossing the worlds Axis. Now I see I have met with a Copernican and it was not the Sun that stood still in Hezekiah's daies, but the Earth, and since he would perswade this, I hope his lyes will gaine no reputation with the Vulgar.

I passe over his Astronomicall Calculations, his going in procession with his Holinesse, and his greatest obliquity from as learned Writers as himselfe, and his Excentricity in being at Oxford no place of his Residence, together with his true and apparent magnitude in part discovered in his many falsityes, and how he takes no notice of those two Ecclipses happening this yeare 1644. at Aulton and Arundell, but none of them seen in their Horizon at Oxford, this lyar has cast such a mist before their eyes, but he will not dispute the effects of either, for he saith, Parvae Eclipses parum nocent, & in pauca operantur, he will not believe till he sees, for, Nihil nocent illis Regionibus in quibus non videntur: He partly knew we were choosing new Sheriffes when he spake of Election, and believes they shall feele their influence be it good or evill: For Phlebotomy in regard bloud is the chiefest humour in mans body, he conceives it d • ngerous at any time, but upon urgent occasions, and the veines which should have been let bloud, fled back to the heart by feare, whence it comes to passe that the Phisitian cannot come at the jugular veine, which makes the Kingdome in such a distemper, that it will never be well till Delinquents be brought to Justice.

The strange humours they have at Oxford are 4, Bloudy, Pragmaticall, Cholerick, Melancholy: the first in the Court, the second in the Colledges, the third in the Camp, the fourth in the City, which drives them in such melancholy dumps that they are at their witts end, and the way to purge is either by neezing, in giving the head better Counsellours, or by vomiting out the evill ones, and then you may find when the moon is fal South at Newcastle, and know when the tide wil serve from thence to bring coals to Towne, but I shall leap over his Leap-year, and come to his great Conjunction of Saturne and Jupiter, and he begins. I am not altogether ignorant, there is more hopes of a foole, he knowes it to be Conjunctio Planitarum maxima, but he wonders at the impudence of some like himselfe that hath neither Art nor honesty, small Art appeares in his Prognostication, and lesse honesty, in perswading many poore seduced people, that all the Victories hapened to the Cavaliers, and to none but they at Oxford, although your Tutor may vouchsafe to use the writings Declarations Protestations, and
Petitions of the Lords and Commons, and may easily see how far it concernes the whole Christian world aswell as England, and not onely England, but as you say, France, Basternia, Syria, Palastina &c. to take heed of Hierchiae aswell as Anarchy, and questionlesse not England only, is concerned in a through Reformation, for the 10. Kings shall hate the whore, and burne her with fire, the Viall is ca • t out on the Throne of the Beast already, I need not tell you of the Effects you are answered already, and for the fixed Stats which hapned at Westminster the 3 of Novemb. 1640. had their light from the Sun, though there was an intervale when it was dissolved, yet it brake through those clouds, and though his Beames were hindred by interposition of those that are not for peace, yet we hope Exurgat & disapenter, but because Iupiter troubles you, Ile deale ingeniously with you, and tell you a Fable of Iupiter. Did you never read of the Ministers of Terrour, who for their cruelty were condemned into Hell by Iupiter? did you never read of the Cyclops voted out of the House, and declared Traitors by his Majesties Proclamations? And did you never read how Tellus perswaded Iupiter that they might doe him service in forging of Thunderbolts? And therefore being banished the Land were sent for in againe by whole Armies, whose paines and industry was grea •
• n providing instruments of terrour, and how Iupiter conceiving displea • ure against an innocent man, the Son of Apollo, for raising a dead man to life, made use of one of these to kill him, but was revenged by Apollo. Make thunderbolts at Oxford, let Naworth be the Cyclop which cast two of his owne framing against Mr. Pym. and the Lord S •… , for endeavouring to revive a sinking Kingdome, let him remember, Apollo may bring him to Iustice, and then • e shall see the effect of the great Conjunction in November he speakes of. Neither, as he saith, can we deduce the signification of this unnaturall war from the conjunction which h • ppened • n February 1642. for we all know what was done above 2 yeares before that time, and what diligence hath been used to bring over Forraigne Forces to suppresse the Parlia • ent of England, witnes the letters and Agents sent into Denmarke, when his Majesty resided in Scotland, and the great offers made to our Brethren there, in case they would assist him against the Parliament in England, and this the meanest capacitie may und • rstand, except they be wilfully blind.

And for those yet fixed stars that fought in their courses, some though extinguished, yet, Spi •…
dehunt tanquam Stella maugre all the malice of their enemies th • t talke of St. Chad, and the Ch •…
grove-Field where Mr. Iohn Hampden fell: Ile tell thee a Heathen could see farther than, you that did not attribute things to Fate when he said.

q.l: Qui suit ex Teucris et servantis simus Equi

div.p: And though they fell in Battaile, yet this is Epitaph enough for each of them, that they were just men, and God saw it good to take them to himselfe, where they now shine as starres, whose height Naworth can never attaine to. And as he he saith, no sooner had the Houses began to Vote, but he began to be sencible of Homo trium litirarum, and that thefts and robberies would follow, and that all the false Prophets in the Kingdome would be convened Heresies and Schismes tollerated, and in his owne words, nay defended so, that I see he would lie if his tongu •… would let him, Subsequens Actus ad viuum exprimat.

Wherein he hopes that the cau • e of all these mischiefes in November at Brainford, so also tha •… o •
February the 13. will be the Forerunner of a through Reformation indeed, by purging it o •… all Sectaries, Brownists, Anabaptists &c. by which he understood the rooting out of the Protestant Rel • gion, and bringing in the Authors of this bloudie war, whereby some of his friends a •…
London conceive the writer of those Forgeries are as void of reason as Loyaltie, and doe therefore w •• h • h • King may take hee • of him, indeed for this Yeares Revolution, we see nothing tha •…
•• a h • n •• r his sac • ed Majesti • from returning againe to his Parliament, were the wicked removed from his Th • one. In the meane time, since the Shi • ld of the mightie is fallen, and the •… Lords annointed is in the Mountaines of Gilboa, set David's wish light upon that mountaine o •… opposition, neque R • s, n • que • luvi • . Let neither raine nor dew f • ll in Oxford till our King be redeemed out of the h • nds of the uncircumcised, and we againe see his face as an Angel of God.

And because I •• l • f • ll • w Naworth in his owne Method, I see no reason why I may not sal • te h •• with that S • lutation, Salv • te Magister Artium Menda • ium, & quidem omnium Aulicor •… Mi • it • nium, Academi a • um.
